findings.title: Error-prone NFT management in the Summoner contract
findings.description: The `Summoner` contract’s ability to hold NFTs in a number of states may create confusion regarding the contracts’ states and the differences between the contracts.

findings.title: Excessive ownership privileges throughout the contracts
findings.description: Any function that can be invoked by a relayer can also be invoked by a contract owner. In all transactions, owners have complete discretion over the account to which funds are sent and the chain on which funds are sent.

findings.title: Widespread lack of data validation
findings.description: Certain data returned in function calls to untrusted external smart contracts is not validated. This lack of validation creates denial-of-service (DoS) attack vectors and can result in unsafe typecasting, which may lead to unexpected behavior.

findings.title: Overly complicated contract and system architecture
findings.description: The system relies heavily on an off-chain system to manage the most critical operations, while the smart contracts primarily emit events to which the off-chain system responds. The primary concern with this design choice is the lack of on-chain safeguards to limit the abilities of the relayer. Secondarily, the intricate smart contract code makes it difficult to reason about the separation of privileges and abilities.

findings.title: Initialization functions can be front-run
findings.description: The `CrosslayerPortal` contracts have initializer functions that can be front-ru, allowing an attacker to incorrectly initialize the contracts.

findings.title: Trades are vulnerable to sandwich attacks
findings.description: The `swapToNative` function lacks protections against high slippage and may cause users to lose funds due to sandwich attacks.

findings.title: forwardCall creates a denial-of-service attack vector
findings.description: The `forwardCall` function is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) attack, which can cause the queue of pending transactions to grow without bounds, resulting in gas costs.

findings.title: Lack of two-step process for contract ownership changes
findings.description: The current implementation of transferOwnership function allows the owner to accidentally set the wrong address and lose access to the contract permanently.

findings.title: sendFunds is vulnerable to reentrancy by owners
findings.description: The `sendFunds` function is vulnerable to reentrancy and can be used by the owner of a token contract to drain the contract of its funds.

findings.title: MosaicVault and MosaicHolding owner has excessive privileges
findings.description: The owner of MosaicVault and MosaicHolding contracts has excessive control over the system, creating a single point of failure and increasing the likelihood of being targeted by an attacker.

findings.title: SushiswapLiquidityProvider deposits cannot be used to cover withdrawal requests
findings.description: Withdrawal requests that require the removal of liquidity from a Sushiswap liquidity pool will revert and cause a system failure.

findings.title: MosaicVault and MosaicHolding owner is controlled by a single private key
findings.description: The owner of MosaicVault and MosaicHolding contracts is a single externally owned account (EOA), creating a single point of failure, making the owner a high-value target for attackers, and increasing incentives for the owner to act maliciously.

findings.title: The relayer is a single point of failure
findings.description: The relayer constitutes a single point of failure within the Mosaic ecosystem and is responsible for managing withdrawals, transfers, accrued interest, cross-chain message calls, fees, and refunds. Its centralized design makes it a likely target for attackers.

findings.title: Project dependencies contain vulnerabilities
findings.description: Dependencies used by CrosslayerPortal have known vulnerabilities, including command injection, exposure of sensitive information, and arbitrary code execution.

findings.title: DoS risk created by cross-chain message call requests on certain networks
findings.description: Cross-chain message calls that are requested on a low-fee, low-latency network could facilitate a DoS, preventing other users from interacting with the system.

findings.title: Missing validation in takeFees function
findings.description: The `takeFees` function takes `calldata` from relayers and contract owners but does not validate the `baseFee` value passed to it, allowing relayers and owners to set arbitrarily large `baseFee` values.

findings.title: Unimplemented getAmountsOut function in Balancer V2
findings.description: The `getAmountsOut` function is not implemented, preventing users from determining how much DAI they will receive before executing a swap on Balancer.

findings.title: Lack of events for critical operations
findings.description: Many functions that perform critical operations do not emit events.

findings.title: Insufficient protection of sensitive information
findings.description: Exposure of sensitive information

findings.title: Accrued interest is not attributable to the underlying investor on-chain
findings.description: When an investor earns interest-bearing tokens by lending funds through Mosaic's investment strategies, the tokens are not directly attributed to the investor by on-chain data.
